user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NotifyEvent:
```c
int32 OS_NotifyEvent(OS_Event_t event, osal_id_t object_id, void *data)
{
    int32 status;

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler != NULL)
    {
        status = OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler(event, object_id, data);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler != NULL)
    {
        status = OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler(event, object_id, data);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation — the controlling expression (OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler != NULL) depends on the runtime value of the function-pointer variable OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler, so it is not invariant. (It would only violate Rule 14.3 if EventHandler were a compile-time or otherwise invariant constant, e.g. #define EventHandler NULL or a const object that never changes.)
